responses.rationale: The segment describes factual events (infections, culling numbers) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment provides factual numbers of birds culled without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment provides factual numbers of birds culled in Iowa without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment provides factual information about Iowa's egg production and chicken population without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment provides factual information about Iowa's turkey production without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the location of the latest cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a confirmed case on a turkey farm without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment contains the intensifier 'so' modifying the risk adjective 'infectious'.
The segment provides factual data on confirmed cases by state without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes the blamed cause of disease spread without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment provides factual information about infected wild birds and virus circulation without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states that cases in birds do not present an immediate public health concern, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states no human cases have been detected and it remains safe to eat poultry, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment provides factual information about cooking temperatures killing pathogens without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment is an editorial note about corrections without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment is an editorial note about corrections without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports confirmed cases in a person and dairy herds without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports FDA findings of trace amounts of H5N1 in milk samples without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports import restrictions and testing without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a statistic on the fatality rate of human cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports animal deaths after drinking raw milk without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states that human-to-human transmission hasn't been detected without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports an increase in raw milk sales without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports an estimate of raw milk consumption without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment links raw milk consumption to other diseases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses social media algorithms and content visibility without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses state regulations on raw milk sales and purchasing hurdles without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a health alert following a confirmed human infection without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a diagnosis of H5N1 in a farm worker without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the only other known US case without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the CDC alert stressing the importance of informing stakeholders about a confirmed human infection with 'highly pathogenic avian influenza', which is a technical term.
The segment recommends PPE use to lower infection risk without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment recommends PPE use when dealing with potentially exposed people without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states risks to the general public remain low, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment urges monitoring patients with symptoms and relevant exposure history without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the lone symptom in the Texas patient without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment lists potential symptoms, including 'serious symptoms', which is a factual description of symptom severity, not an intensified risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment reports a statistic on the death rate of human cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment stresses the importance of following recommendations to reduce outbreak chances without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment urges common-sense measures despite risks being low, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment advises avoiding sick/dead animals or contaminated surfaces without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses concerns about potential future outbreaks and the lack of known human-to-human transmission without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment reports public health officials expressing concerns following the discovery of cases in cattle, describing a reaction ('expressed concerns') rather than using an intensified risk adjective.
The segment describes the outbreak's spread without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives. 'quickly spread' is a vivid verb describing a background condition.

The segment reports testing results showing no genetic changes that would increase human infection likelihood or hinder antiviral effectiveness without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the first outbreak and confirmation of 'highly pathogenic avian influenza', which is a technical term.
The segment reports the number of chickens being exterminated and restricted zones without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states there is no possibility of transmission through consumption, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states an increase in human infections is turning into a source of concern, describing a reaction ('source of concern') rather than using an intensified risk adjective.
The segment reports the number of human infections, deaths, and critically ill cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports outbreaks in Europe and the number of poultry affected without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes Japan's worst season of winter flu on farms, using a comparative ('worst') that modifies 'season' rather than a risk adjective describing the virus or its impact.
The segment reports that ground beef samples tested negative for H5N1 without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports negative test results and reaffirms the meat supply is safe, which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment reports efforts to confirm the safety of products following virus detection in cattle herds without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a confirmed case in a person without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment states the overall public health risk is low but higher for those with exposure, using reassuring language ('low risk', 'higher risk') but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment describes arduous work and disinfection procedures without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment introduces H5N1 bird flu as something to contend with without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment contains the intensifier 'highly, highly' modifying the risk adjective 'transmissible'.
The segment uses a metaphor ('Swiss Army Knife') and reports factual outcomes ('infected and killed millions') without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the virus being found in different mammals without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment uses a vivid noun ('voraciousness') and quotes a classification ('global zoonotic animal pandemic') but does not contain an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment uses a metaphor ('collateral damage') but does not contain an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states humans can be infected and speculates about potential change without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment uses a comparative ('higher rate') modifying 'rate', not a risk adjective.
The segment discusses viral errors and fitness without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses viral changes and spread without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment speculates about the animal pandemic becoming a 'major problem' for people, using 'major' to modify 'problem' rather than a risk adjective.
The segment describes a personal reaction ('nothing had prepared him') without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes animal symptoms and the onset of seizures without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a description of seizures ('severe, severe seizures'), where 'severe' modifies 'seizures' (an outcome/symptom), not a risk adjective describing the virus itself.
The segment quotes a description of symptoms ('Screaming very loud, whole-body tremors'), where 'very loud' modifies 'screaming' (a symptom), not a risk adjective describing the virus itself.
The segment uses a comparative ('longer') modifying duration, not a risk adjective.
The segment states the person hadn't known the animals could get bird flu without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states foxes joined a 'growing list' of species that could succumb, using a comparative ('growing') that modifies 'list' rather than a risk adjective.
The segment quotes a statement about the 'severity' of seizures, where 'severity' is a noun, not an intensified risk adjective.
The segment quotes a statement about the progression of the disease being 'a very sad thing', where 'very sad' modifies 'thing', not a risk adjective.
The segment states infections have been sporadic and self-limiting without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus can be 'deadly' (a factual characteristic here) and reports a fatality statistic, but does not use an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the virus rarely gets passed to someone else without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a technical term ('dead-end infections') without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.

The segment explains how a dead-end infection happens, mentioning a 'large amount' of virus and an immune system being 'too weak', but these do not constitute an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment states the virus is not well-adapted to humans without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the number of dead-end infections in dairy workers without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports symptoms developed by workers without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a specific instance of exposure without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports symptoms developed by a worker without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports successful treatment without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports outcomes (no severe symptoms, no infection of others) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports that the virus is unlikely to transmit through the air without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes an experiment to infect ferrets without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes placing healthy ferrets with sick ones without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes the outcome of ferrets becoming ill after contact without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes testing airborne transmission without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the outcome of the airborne transmission test and states the virus is not well adapted to respiratory spread without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the number of positive herds and states the number of human infections has been 'low', which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment reports the outcome of the airborne transmission test and states the findings are 'good news', which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the agency plans to repeat tests without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment uses a comparison ('As Covid has shown') and states things could change quickly without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states more opportunity to spread means more opportunity to change without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement that viruses can change 'very quickly', where 'very quickly' modifies 'change', not a risk adjective.
The segment quotes a statement that viruses can adapt and spread 'very easily', where 'very easily' modifies 'spread', not a risk adjective.
The segment states H5N1 would look 'pretty different' to our bodies, which is a factual description, not an intensified risk adjective.
The segment states existing immunity is not necessarily going to protect against H5 without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the study had 'sobering findings', describing the nature of the findings, not using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment reports that H5N1 killed all infected ferrets, which is a factual outcome, not an intensified risk adjective.

The segment quotes a statement that while US cases have been mild, 'serious illnesses' are possible, using 'serious' to describe the illness outcome, not an intensified risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment states there has been a 'wide spectrum of severity' in human infections, which is a factual description, not an intensified risk adjective.
The segment lists the number of cases by severity ('severe or critical', 'fatal', 'mild'), which are factual descriptions of outcomes, not intensified risk adjectives describing the virus.
The segment discusses potential reasons for symptom severity differences without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states experiments suggest bodies wouldn't necessarily be 'totally defenseless', which is reassuring language but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.

The segment reports experimental results showing ferrets didn't get 'as sick' (comparative modifying an outcome) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives describing the virus.
The segment states the strains involved in the cattle outbreak haven't been tested without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses antibodies and memory cells without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses the difficulty of predicting help from past exposures and the importance of vaccination without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the US has vaccines in stockpile and doses are being prepared without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports Finland ordering vaccine doses to protect workers without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the risk to the general public is 'low' and higher for workers, using reassuring language ('low risk', 'higher risk') but not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment reports protective equipment and funding being made available without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses challenges related to wearing protective equipment without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the government is working on developing a rapid test without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses symptom severity potentially depending on virus exposure amount without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment discusses smaller doses leading to 'milder symptoms' (comparative modifying an outcome) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives describing the virus.
The segment discusses ingesting large amounts of virus leading to 'severe disease', using 'severe' to describe the outcome, not an intensified risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment states the virus can infect internal organs without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus doesn't just locate in the lungs without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus has been found in various organs without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states a person agrees with a previous statement without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement calling the virus 'at the top of the list in terms of bad guy viruses', which is informal/metaphorical, not an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the virus goes to the brain and causes 'very, very severe disease', where 'very, very severe' modifies 'disease' (an outcome), not a risk adjective describing the virus itself.
The segment states infected animals behave strangely or aggressively without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment describes the behaviour of infected ducks without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement about causing 'very, very severe disease' (outcome) and a personal reaction ('hate to see it') without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.

The segment states the virus hasn't made changes to become a human pathogen and it's unclear if it ever will, discussing potential/uncertainty without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment quotes a statement about studying the virus and looking for evidence of human transmission, stating it hasn't been seen yet, without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment quotes a statement about being amazed at how the virus has changed and looking for evidence of human transmission, stating it hasn't been seen yet, without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports attempts to save fox kits and their deaths without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports other foxes survived but went blind without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states precautions were arduous but effective without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus was never spread to other animals or themselves without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus was never spread and quotes a comparison ('kind of like when Covid went through') without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the person hasn't encountered infected animals recently but is watching the news without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment contains the intensifier 'highly, highly' modifying the risk adjective 'contagious'. 'spread kind of like wildfire' is a vivid verb/metaphor but describes a background condition.
The segment states farmers are 'on edge' (describing a reaction) and mentions 'highly pathogenic avian influenza' (a technical term). 'on the rise' describes a trend.
The segment discusses rising prices without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment contains 'highly contagious' modifying 'bird flu'. 'bird flu' is not a specific virus name like H5N1 or HPAI, so the technical term guard does not apply.
The segment states disease precautions prevented visiting farms without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment states it's 'rare' for people to get infected (reassuring language) and calls it a 'death sentence' for birds (metaphor for outcome), but does not contain an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the whole flock has to go if one bird is infected without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states an association is watching the outbreak closely and reports the first case date without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states affected poultry need to be de-populated without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states depopulation stops the virus without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement about not wanting the farm spreading the virus without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the person is the state veterinarian without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the number of affected birds and states the industry is 'extremely large', where 'extremely large' modifies 'industry', not a risk adjective.
The segment quotes a statement about being the No. 1 turkey producing state without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states chicken prices rise as bird flu hits farmers without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the cost of eggs has doubled without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the person owns a company and raises a certain amount of turkey without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states they haven't had an outbreak but are 'anxiously watching' (describing a reaction) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement about potentially being the next case and not knowing how to deal with it, using 'very easily' to modify likelihood ('be the next one'), not a risk adjective.
The segment states the company is the only mobile processing company without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states their season will look different as the flu 'tears through' farms, using a vivid verb ('tears through') describing a background condition (spread).
The segment discusses not bringing equipment because it can't be gotten 'as clean' (comparative modifying cleanliness) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment states equipment has to be 'absolutely sterile' (intensifier modifying cleanliness) or they will spread it and cause problems, without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the number of affected birds, states, and flocks without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment lists the hardest hit states, using a comparative ('hardest hit') that modifies 'states' rather than a risk adjective.
The segment states the department pays farmers for culled birds but uncertainty remains without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement calling it a 'Scary thing' (personal feeling) and questioning if the safety net will be there without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.

The segment quotes a statement calling it a 'Scary thing' (personal feeling) and stating it's going to be 'devastating', which describes an economic/business outcome, not an intensified risk adjective describing the virus.

The segment quotes a statement stating it's going to be 'devastating' (economic/business outcome) and put a company out of business 'very fast' (intensifier modifying speed), without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment reports states banning poultry events to get a handle on the virus without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment asks poultry owners to watch for unusual signs and call authorities without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the virus is carried by wild birds without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states new cases are expected to stop when wild birds migrate without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment reports authorities preparing to destroy hens in the 'biggest outbreak' (comparative modifying 'outbreak') without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective describing the virus.
The segment reports bird flu was reported after an increase of deaths without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states the majority of the flock could be spared without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement that the whole hall population will have to be culled without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a decision against poultry exhibits amid 'avian flu concerns' (describing a reaction/reason) without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment quotes a statement about erring on the side of caution without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports the first confirmed case of a strain of 'highly pathogenic avian flu virus', which is a technical term.
The segment reports the number of confirmed cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states most states have reported cases without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.

The segment states the risk to human health is 'low' (reassuring) but the virus is 'highly contagious' among birds. 'highly contagious' is followed by 'among birds', not a specific virus name like H5N1 or HPAI, so the technical term guard does not apply.
The segment reports officials opted against including poultry without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports condor deaths and efforts to determine the cause for others without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports a condor died and tested positive for 'Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI)', which is a technical term.
The segment reports other birds tested positive or results are pending without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports capturing and sending ill birds to a rescue without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment reports one bird died and others were quarantined without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states exposure is expected to rise during migration without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states HPAI hasn't been detected in other populations without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states avian flu occurs mainly in birds but has been found in other animals and states without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
The segment states humans are considered at 'low risk' (reassuring language) from HPAI without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the risk of human-to-human spread appears 'low' (reassuring language) without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment describes a past pandemic where a strain 'spread rapidly' (vivid verb describing a background condition) without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment states the outbreak turned out to be 'mild' (describing the outcome) without using an intensifier/comparative modifying a risk adjective.
The segment reports the first case of a strain being passed to humans and reported to the WHO without using intensifiers or comparatives modifying risk adjectives.
